data.text: What Multitool Components Would Be Useful for Bike Tours?

I've bought myself a Topeak Hexus X multitool, which I feel is a good choice and not too small and fiddly. But my question is what additional multitool components do people find useful e.g. pliers, scissors etc. And which multitool do people recommend? I am looking for something fairly basic and lightweight for short tours. I could also be in the market for an even smaller everyday carry tool. Thank in advance for your suggestions.
I love my Topeak alien 2, it’s always in the saddlebag, I’ve a small pair of needlenose pliers in it as well, just for getting stuff out the tyres when I’ve had a puncture
data.author: Anatoli Bugorski

data.text: brilliant, this is the kind of thing I am meaning, also tools to use off the bike whilst touring. With regard to puncture and first aid, I just watched a video on the Swiss Army Explorer knife which has tweezers, a straight pin and a magnifying glass. But I've heard needlenose pliers can equally be used to remove splinters from human skin and tyres.
data.author: William Gilmour

data.text: I've had the same topeak alien tool for 15 yrs. Always comes in handy, had a good chain breaker on it which is a must have tool.
data.author: Ryan Parker

data.text: lots of votes for the Alien! Although the Hexus X also has a solid chain breaker, and a replacement pin can be ordered as a spare part. And of course I am carrying the necessary quicklinks.
data.author: William Gilmour

data.text: I have an earlier version of the Hexus and it is my favorite. Maybe check out the Topeak Alien which has more tools in it and may be a good choice for touring. I also have an early version of that and a similar one by Park Tool.
data.author: Steve Reisman

data.text: Thanks, I feel the Hexus gives me enough bike tools, it is the other more general toolset I am looking to add right now. Maybe I will find I need the Alien further down the line? Thanks for your comment.
data.author: William Gilmour

data.text: Another Alien 2 user here but the key extras I have are: NBT2 for cassette removal Small adjustable spanner Tie-wraps Tyre levers
data.author: Mark Litherland

data.text: I’ve carried a multi tool for years on tour. However I think I am going to change to carrying individual longer Alan keys. This is because I find my multi tool Allen keys are just not long enough for certain jobs - even though they are one of the longer multitools. Also many things on the multi tool are not needed. I plan to carry a 3,4,5,6 size. I have also replaced all torx bolts with allen equivalents. I also carry a separate chain breaker, mini cassette removal tool and a small pair of pliers. Oh and small size JSI screwdriver to adjust stop screws.
data.author: Roger Leary

data.text: I feel there is a home exercise to attempt to reach and loosen/tighten every bolt etc that you would want to be able to adjust on tour. And then add the requisite additional tools. 5mm allen key is what I have come up with so far for my own needs. Personally, I am only looking to master a limited skill set, and so can skip pedal, crank bolts etc. In terms of tools not needed, that is a point in favour of a multi tool such as the Hexus X which is mainly allen keys and torx keys. Also, looking at the grip and leverage available on both sides of the Hexus X chain tool, I am struggling to imagine a portable chain tool which is a marked improvement on that. But thanks for sharing some pointers as to what a more complete touring toolset might look like.
data.author: William Gilmour

data.text: , I found I needed a longer size 3 key to adjust disc pad distance (at the disc). I had a brake lever come slightly loose, needed to go to a bike shop for a longer size 5 key to tighten. I couldn't undo a pedal with my size 6 key, though managed eventually. ( even though I had loosened pedals at the beginning of my tour). Minor issues with the right tools but a pain with my multitool (Crank Bros). All of these issues have made me reconsider.
data.author: Roger Leary

data.text: I have a small leatherman tool with needle-nose pliers that’s definitely handy on a tour.
data.author: Ivan Liew

data.text: thanks, this is the real question I was asking. I know the larger Leatherman can be quite heavy so am curious which small one you went for.
data.author: William Gilmour

data.text: agreed, I bought a leatherman and it weighed a ton! I now carry a small, generic multitool with needle nose pliers. Perfectly adequate for me and a third of the weight. However I can no longer remove stones from horses hooves.....
data.author: Roger Leary

data.text: One of the smallest mini ones with pliers. Smaller than average Swiss Army. Many generic brands available too.
data.author: Ivan Liew

data.text: thanks, that sounds a good way to do it. As a Swiss army knife with pliers is going to be huge, and the pliers v. small.
data.author: William Gilmour
